Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Story: I was sitting in the living room, trying to focus on my homework, when I heard my dog barking loudly in the hallway again. I knew Mrs. Kim from next door would be annoyed—she’d already left a note last week about the noise. I felt a knot in my stomach, knowing I should do something to keep the peace. At the same time, I could hear my stepdad sighing in the kitchen. He’d been quiet all evening, and I remembered Mom telling me he’d had a rough day at work. I wanted to check in, to ask if everything was okay at home, like I always tried to do. But if I left the dog alone, he’d keep barking and probably upset the neighbors even more. If I stayed to calm the dog, I’d miss the chance to support my parents when they might need me. I stood in the hallway, torn between the closed kitchen door and the leash hanging by the entrance, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
